subject: RE: [junit] How to run same testcase with 20 different  arg-values to test diff. results
msgSnippet: Also what about.... taking original test case extract the test case code into a private method, to which the params are passed.  Then in the original test case
messageBody:
Also what about....


taking original test case extract the test case code into a private method,
to which the params are passed. Then in the original test case method, we
simply call the private one n times with different param values.

Original code:

public void testIntegers() {

assertEquals(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
assertEquals(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
}


would then become...


public void testIntegers() {
testTwoIntegers(Integer.maxValue, Integer.maxValue);
testTwoIntegers(Integer.minValue, Integer.minValue);
testTwoIntegers(new Integer(232), new Integer(232));
...
}


private void testTwoIntegers(Integer expected, Integer actual) {
// Setup could even be called from here if needed!

assertEquals(expected, actual);

// If setup is called from here, then you'd no doubt want to cal tearDown
as well
}




> -----Original Message-----
> From: J. B. Rainsberger [mailto:jbrains@...]
> Sent: 22 July 2003 17:02
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] How to run same testcase with 20 different
> arg-values to test diff. results
>
>
> >So said suyash_says on 2003-07-22 --------------------
> >
> > Hello every one. !!!
> > Pls help me. i want to run the same testcase with 20
> >different set of values of an arg that gives me 20 unique results. I
> >don't want to hard code these values. Is there some dynamic way to do
> >so that doesn't increase overheades of writing test case.
> > Regds
> > - Suyash
>
> Yes, there is. Here is a sketch of the solution.
>
> 1. Add a constructor to your TestCase subclass that accepts the
> parameters you want to use for each test. Store those parameters
> in the test fixture (instance variables).
> 2. Create ONE test method that uses the test fixture and runs the test.
> 3. Create a suite() method that loops through your test data and
> uses your new constructor to push test data into the test fixture.
>
> You can code your suite() method any way you want: it can read
> data from a file or a database, for example.
>
> A more complete example will be available in the book "JUnit
> Cookbook" sometime in late 2003/early 2004. :)
>
> Take care.
>
>
> J. B. Rainsberger,
